block.p: Here is a selective guide to cultural events in New York and beyond in the months ahead. As usual, programs change, some events are sold out, and some have not yet scheduled locations or exact opening dates. Unless indicated, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan, and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear at the bottom of page 68. September

DANSPACE AT ST. MARK'S CHURCH -- There will be wide-ranging dance at this intimate, light-filled space, starting tonight and continuing through June. Among the participants are the lithe and lyrical Bill Young (Oct. 5-8), the relative newcomers Nicholas Leichter (Nov. 19) and Wally Cardona (Dec. 7-10), and the evocative Nancy Meehan (March 29-31). 131 E. 10th St. (674-8112)

Here is a selective guide to cultural events in New York and beyond in the months ahead. As usual, programs change, some events are sold out, and some have not yet scheduled locations or exact opening dates. Unless indicated, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan, and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear at the bottom of page 68. September

DANSPACE AT ST. MARK'S CHURCH -- There will be wide-ranging dance at this intimate, light-filled space, starting tonight and continuing through June. Among the participants are the lithe and lyrical Bill Young (Oct. 5-8), the relative newcomers Nicholas Leichter (Nov. 19) and Wally Cardona (Dec. 7-10), and the evocative Nancy Meehan (March 29-31). 131 E. 10th St. (674-8112)

DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP -- The fall season at this pioneering little dance theater begins with experimentalist choreography from Minnesota (Mon.) and ends 14 events later with New York's own Ann Carlson (Dec. 13-30). 219 W. 19th St. (924-0077)

DIA CENTER -- An indispensable grass-roots home for dance, the center opens with the Spaulding-Schoenberg Dance Cycle, a sampling of new choreography (Thur.-Fri.), and includes the always-provocative New Dance Alliance Performance Mix (Oct. 16).

PERFORMANCE SPACE 122 -- Predictably unpredictable, the dance season opens with Susan Rethorst and a dance to be "wrecked" and then reconstructed by invited artists (Thur. to Sept. 17) and ends with a relatively new kid on the block, Benoit LeChambre (June 13-16).

COMPAGNIE MAGUY MARIN -- Belgian stew and Samuel Beckett are the inspirations for two new full-length works by this French modern-dance choreographer, who turned Cinderella and her friends into Cabbage Patch lookalikes (Sept. 19-30). Joyce Theater.
JOAN MILLER'S DANCE PLAYERS -- A 25th-anniversary season, featuring works inspired by the writings of the essayist and poet Maya Angelou (Sept. 22-23). Florence Gould Hall, 55 E. 59th St. (355-6160)

LA MAMA E.T.C. -- A tiny theater with wide horizons, La Mama will present dance from eight countries on three continents in a season that opens Sept. 23 and runs through June. Highlights include the impudent Poppo and the Go Go Boys (Feb. 29-March 3) and the haunting minimalist Kei Takei (June 27-30). October

TANGO X 2 -- A new production by the creators of the wildly popular "Tango Argentino" (Oct. 1). Lehman Center for the Arts, Lehman College, Bronx (718-960-8833) (Oct. 8). Tilles Center, Long Island University, C. W. Post Campus, Greenvale, N.Y. (516-299-3100)

RALPH LEMON COMPANY -- A 10th-anniversary season and farewell from this thought-provoking modern-dance troupe, featuring new works inspired by old friendships and a tulip-eating cat (Oct. 3-8). Joyce Theater.

MURRAY LOUIS DANCE COMPANY/HOMMAGE AUX BALLETS SUEDOIS -- A modernist pays tribute to modernism of another era, in conjunction with the Guggenheim Museum and the Fashion Institute of Technology (Oct. 9-10). John Jay College Theater, 899 10th Ave., at 58th St. (423-3575).
PAUL TAYLOR DANCE COMPANY -- A quizzical master takes on France during the belle epoque in his new "Offenbach Overtures" (Oct. 10-22). City Center.

MARIA BENITEZ TEATRO FLAMENCO -- A practitioner of modern flamenco finds inspiration in the past with "El Amor Brujo" and offers an hommage to the legendary dancer La Argentina (Oct. 17-29). Joyce Theater.

DORIS HUMPHREY CENTENNIAL -- Several events will celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of this modern matriarch, among them an ambitious festival featuring Humphrey's entire surviving oeuvre, produced by the Doris Humphrey Repertory Dance Company (Oct. 17-21; Mar. 8-11) at Pace Downtown Theater, and a three-day conference (Oct. 20-22) that includes a performance at La Guardia Concert Hall, 64th St. and Amsterdam Ave. (721-9634)
CLOUD GATE DANCE THEATER -- Part of the Next Wave Festival. A look back 2,000 years in the new "Nine Songs," inspired by ancient Chinese ritual poems (Oct. 18-21). Brooklyn Academy of Music.

BROOKLYN CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS AT BROOKLYN COLLEGE -- The Big Daddy of outer-borough arts presenters, BCBC opens its dance series with the North Carolina Dance Theater (Oct. 29) and closes with Ballet South from Alabama in "Swan Lake" (April 14). Whitman Hall, Brooklyn College, Flatbush and Nostrand Aves. (718-951-4500)
COMPAGNIE MARIE CHOUINARD -- A Canadian modernist tackles Diaghilev with new versions of two Ballets Russes classics (Oct. 31-Nov. 5). Joyce Theater.

SAN FRANCISCO BALLET -- Gossamer light and poised in style, this classical company goes somewhat modern in New York premieres by the guest choreographers James Kudelka, David Bintley and Mark Morris (Oct. 31-Nov. 5). City Center. November
TORONTO DANCE THEATER -- Modern dance from a company -- and a choreographer, Christopher House -- with a solid sense of craft (Nov. 7-12). Joyce Theater.

MARTHA GRAHAM DANCE COMPANY -- Graham's eager dancers may do a lot of standing still with the avant-gardist Robert Wilson's new "Snow on the Mesa," a highlight of the troupe's season. Set to Balinese music, the piece seeks to evoke Graham's unquenchable spirit (Nov. 9-12). City Center.
LIMON DANCE COMPANY -- A major modern-dance troupe in a season celebrating the centennial of the American modern-dance pioneer Doris Humphrey (Nov. 14-26). Joyce Theater.
EIKO AND KOMA -- To mark their 20th anniversary, these Japanese minimalists have created film and dance inspired by the silent autumn forests (Nov. 16-18). Japan Society.
JULIO BOCCA/BALLET ARGENTINO -- This company, which was founded in 1990, makes its New York debut with some starry razzle-dazzle and earthy tango dancing (Nov. 16-19). City Center.

NEW YORK CITY BALLET -- George Balanchine's beloved "Nutcracker," along with the return of Jerome Robbins's "West Side Story Suite," and new ballets by David Parsons and the company director, Peter Martins. Mr. Martins's score, by Charles Wuorinen, pays tribute to Balanchine's old pal Stravinsky (Nov. 21-Feb. 25). The company will, of course, be back in the spring, though no repertory has been announced (April 23-June 23). New York State Theater.
DAVID ROUSSEVE -- "The Whispers of Angels," a Next Wave Festival premiere, draws on mixed media for a choreographic portrait of a gay black man (Nov. 28-Dec. 3). Brooklyn Academy of Music.

BALLET HISPANICO OF NEW YORK -- A 25th-anniversary retrospective for a troupe that has stayed vibrantly youthful while building the stylish crossover repertory of its maturity (Nov. 28-Dec. 10). Joyce Theater. December
IMPROVISATIONAL DANCE AT THE KITCHEN Performances by Steve Paxton and Simone Forti, two seminal figures in the field, and their heirs (Dec. 1-10).

ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER Hot-blooded and cool-headed dance and dancers, with new works by Judith Jamison, Shapiro and Smith, revivals, a tribute to Masazumi Chaya, the company's irrepressible associate director, and a bow to that classic of modern dance, "Revelations," now 35 (Dec. 6-31). City Center.

MORRIS DANCE GROUP -- The protean modernist offers two programs of new and old works in the Next Wave Festival whose titles alone -- try "Lucky Charms" and "Jesu, Meine Freude," for example -- suggest the range and sophistication of Mr. Morris's interests. Premieres include dances set to music by Stephen Foster and Lou Harrison as well as "The Office," a somber metaphor for recent historical events (Dec. 9-17). Brooklyn Academy of Music.
STREB/RINGSIDE -- Dancing athletes in playful but punishing confrontations with large objects, usually inanimate, and often miked (Dec. 12-31). Joyce Theater.
BLONDELL CUMMINGS AND JUNKO KIKUCHI Two strong performers, one black and one Asian, in "Women in the Dunes," to jazz by Deidre L. Murray (Dec. 14-15). Japan Society. January
WASHINGTON BALLET -- A rare New York performance by a major American classical troupe (Jan. 23-28). Joyce Theater.
DOUG VARONE AND DANCERS -- Expect to see dance pouring out in a high-energy flow in Varone's lush yet emotionally probing choreography (Jan. 30-Feb. 4). Joyce Theater. February

MERCE CUNNINGHAM DANCE COMPANY -- A master adventurer and his lively troupe in 90-minute dance collages he calls "events." Performable in everything from closets to football fields, they sometimes encapsulate an entire career (Feb. 6-11). Joyce Theater.
ERICK HAWKINS DANCE COMPANY -- Modern dance as luminous, meditative poetry, with odd and haunting masks and sets and stirring music (Feb. 13-18). Joyce Theater.
FELD BALLETS/NY -- A prickly romantic and his popular young classical company in works new and old (Feb. 20-Mar. 31). Joyce Theater. April

BEBE MILLER COMPANY -- Sensuous, brainy and even funny, Ms. Miller focuses this time on the famous "silent twins" of England and their isolating private world in the new "Tiny Sisters in the Enormous Land," a dance with video and text (April 16-21). Joyce Theater.

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER -- Something for everyone, with Ben Stevenson's lush production of "Cinderella," works by Jiri Kylian and Twyla Tharp, and revivals, including Balanchine's "Apollo" and "Ballet Imperial" and Antony Tudor's "Leaves Are Fading" (April 29-June 13). Metropolitan Opera House.
GARTH FAGAN DANCE -- A 25-year retrospective by a distinctive modern-dance stylist (April 30-May 12). Joyce Theater. June
BILL T. JONES / ARNIE ZANE DANCE COMPANY -- Mr. Jones returns to short dances, typically filled with vivid distillation of thought and emotion (June 11-23). Joyce Theater. THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR
